pathogen.name: E. coli
pathogen.description: A coliform, rod-shaped bacterium, Escherichia coli are commonly found in the gut.
pathogen.hint: Many strains of E. coli are part of the gut's normal microbiota. It's probably okay to ignore it.
pathogen.question: It's just normal E. coli. Enter "okay" to continue.

pathogen.name: Salmonella
pathogen.description: A capsular bacterium that uses its many flagella to travel from place to place, Salmonella targets the stomach.
pathogen.hint: It looks like this pathogen is able to produce energy regardless of its surroundings. Perhaps a general attack can do the trick.
pathogen.question: Salmonella is wreaking havoc. A pyrrhic victory is still a victory. Call the help of which self-sacrificing cell?

pathogen.name: C. difficile
pathogen.description: Clostridiodes difficile, a motile, drumstick-shaped bacteria.
pathogen.hint: C. difficile is spore-forming. Better not take too long fighting it.
pathogen.question: This requires immediate action. Which cells of the innate immune system should be used?

pathogen.name: Chlamydia psittaci
pathogen.description: Psittaci, a zoonotic bacterium responsible for parrot fever, presents chiefly as an atypical pneumonia that can lead to a coma.
pathogen.hint: It looks like it might be susceptible to bacteriophages.
pathogen.question: This typically requires tetracyclines. In the mean time, which cells should take action?

pathogen.name: Fungal Meningitis
pathogen.description: An altered state of mind, nausea clouding your head. When did the lights become so intense? The spore-forming fungal meningitis blends into the pellucid cerebrospinal fluid as it finishes its travel from the lungs.
pathogen.hint: The fungus boasts a mortality rate of 10-20% amongst its afflicted. Fortunately, it's not transmissible between humans. It'll take a while to defeat this.
pathogen.question: The blood-brain barrier makes this especially tricky. Which cells should be used to extirpate the fungal fury?

pathogen.name: Prion
pathogen.description: The harbinger of many transmissible neurodegenerative pathogens (e.g., Creutzfeldt-Jakob pathogen, Chronic Wasting pathogen, spongiform encephalopathy), prions denature the brain's proteins, invariably leading to death.
pathogen.hint: Prions are durable, proteinaceous extremophiles. Beyond the host's life, these proteins remain virulent. Death is ineluctable.
pathogen.question: Nothing can be done. Accept death and make amends. Play again?
